result.execSummary:
The defendant John Odom Jr was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Bail Jumping-Felony, a class H felony, Wisconsin Statutes 946.49(1)(b).

Charge(s) in this case were read in to this or other case(s). A "read in" charge is a charge that is dismissed as part of a plea agreement, however:

  • The defendant agrees to have the court consider the charge(s) when sentencing for another crime, under Wis. Stats. 973.20(1g)(b); and
  • The defendant cannot be prosecuted for these charge(s) in the future.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

supervisions.notes:
Defendant is NOT eligible for Challenge Incarceration Program. 
Defendant is NOT eligible for Substance Abuse Program. 
Sentence credit of 123 days was granted.
Consecutive to: any other sentence if revoked.
Consecutive to: all other initial Confinement and Extended Supervision

miscConds.notes:
-Standard court costs waived. DNA Surcharge to be paid as a condition of Extended Supervision. 
-Defendant to provide DNA sample, if not yet provided, immediately if in custody otherwise within (3) business days at the Waukesha County Sheriff Department.
-Submit to an AODA assessment, follow through with any treatment, counseling.  No use or possession of alcohol or illegal drugs/drug paraphernalia. Maintain absolute sobriety.

-Obtain/maintain full-time employment. 
-No contact with any victim listed in the criminal complaint. 
-Mental health evaluation and treatment deemed appropriate. 
-If Probation/Extended Supervision is revoked and/or a prison term ordered, outstanding financial obligations shall be collected pursuant to statutory provisions, including deductions from inmate prison monies.  If discharged with outstanding financial obligations, a civil judgment shall be entered against the defendant and in favor of restitution victims and government entities for outstanding financial obligations.  Collections may include income assignment.

Defendant to comply with I.D. Processing.  Defendant to have no contact with Meijer's listed in the Criminal Complaint.  Absolute sobriety, defendant is not to possess or consume any alcohol.  Defendant is not to use/possess any controlled substances without a valid prescription and take as prescribed.  Defendant not to possess any drug paraphernalia.  Defendant to report/comply with Wisconsin Community Services Pretrial Supervision Program under Level 4 supervision.  The defendant is ordered to comply with CAM monitoring and/or drug testing through WCS.  CAM duration and/or drug testing frequency pursuant to Pretrial Supervision Program protocols.  Defendant to pay costs associated with CAM and/or drug testing.  Defendant to be released during regular business hours only and is to report directly to Wisconsin Community Services upon release.

01:32 PM Defendant John Odom in court, in custody, with State Public Defender Law Intern.    District Attorney's Office Law Intern appeared for the State of Wisconsin.  Defendant is eligible for State Public Defender representation.  An attorney will be appointed.  Attorney John Marchan will likely be appointed as he represents the defendant on his other matter.  Defense acknowledges receipt of complaint and waives reading of complaint.  Service admitted/advised of charges and potential penalties.  Defense requests a status of counsel date.  Court tolled time limits for preliminary hearing.  Court notes defendant currently is set for plea and sentencing on his other matters tomorrow.  The Court will set a status of counsel date tomorrow before Judge Dorow and if matter needs to be set back for a preliminary hearing, it may be set back before Commissioner Court.  Hearing scheduled for March 31, 2022 at 02:30 pm.
